TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit CollectionView extends System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject implements class System.Collections.IEnumerable, class System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged, class System.ComponentModel.ICollectionView, class System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged

Docs.summary: Represents a view for grouping, sorting, filtering, and navigating a data collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You should not create objects of this class in your code. To create a collection view for a collection that only implements , create a object, add your collection to the property, and get the collection view from the property. You can think of a collection view as a layer on top of a binding source collection that allows you to navigate and display the collection based on sort, filter, and group queries, all without having to manipulate the underlying source collection itself. If the source collection implements the interface, the changes that raise the event are propagated to the views. Because a view does not change the underlying source collection, a source collection can have multiple views associated with it. By using views, you can display the same data in different ways. For example, you can use two views on a collection of `Task` objects to show tasks sorted by priority on one part of the page and grouped by area on another part of the page. In [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] applications, all collections have an associated default collection view. Rather than working with the collection directly, the binding engine always accesses the collection through the associated view. To get the default view, use the method. An internal class based on is the default view for collections that implement only . is the default view for collections that implement . is the default view for collections that implement or . Alternatively, you can create a view of your collection in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_xaml](~/includes/tlasharptla-xaml-md.md)] by using the class and then bind your control to that view. The class is the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] representation of the class. For an example, see [How to: Sort and Group Data Using a View in XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/how-to-sort-and-group-data-using-a-view-in-xaml.md). For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md). To set a view in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)], use the class. is the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] representation of the class, and it exposes the most commonly used members of the class. ## XAML Text Usage See Remarks

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class that represents a view of the specified collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The instance of <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> is bound to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher of the caller of this constructor.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports filtering.
Docs.value: if the view supports filtering; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If this property returns `false`, setting the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> property throws an exception.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports grouping.
Docs.value: in all cases.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions%2A>. Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support grouping.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports sorting.
Docs.value: in all cases.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A>. Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support sorting.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool Contains(object item) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item belongs to the view.
Docs.returns: if the item belongs to the view; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method does not make any assumptions about whether the item belongs to the underlying collection. If the caller knows that the item belongs to the underlying collection, it is more efficient to call the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.PassesFilter%2A> method.

Docs.summary: Gets the number of records in the view.
Docs.value: The number of records in the view, or –1 if the number of records is unknown.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If a filter is set, this property value only includes items that pass the filter. If the underlying collection is of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>, this is an O(N) operation. This value is cached until the collection changes.

block.para: When deriving from , override this property to provide a more efficient implementation.

Docs.value: The culture information to use during sorting.

Docs.summary: Occurs after the has changed.

block.para: Raise this event after changing the .

Docs.summary: Occurs when the is changing.

block.para: Raise this event before changing the .

Docs.summary: Gets the current item in the view.
Docs.value: The current item of the view. By default, the first item of the collection starts as the current item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
Note that moving the current record pointer has some interactions with any sorting or filtering that is applied to the collection. Sorting preserves the current record pointer on the last record selected, but the collection view is restructured around it. (Perhaps the selected record was at the beginning of the list before, but now the selected record might be somewhere in the middle.) Filtering preserves the selected record if that selection remains in view after the filtering. Otherwise, the current record pointer is set to the first record of the filtered collection view.
The current item of the collection is bound to automatically if the target of a binding is a singleton value. If the target is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, the current item is synchronized with the selected item. For example, if a list box is bound to a collection, the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> is synchronized with the currently selected item.

block.para: Only classes that pass currency handling calls to another internal object should override this property; all other derived classes should use the method to update the current values stored in the base class.

Docs.summary: Gets the ordinal position of the within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.
Docs.value: The ordinal position of the within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.

block.para: Only classes that pass currency handling calls to another internal object should override this property; all other derived classes should use the method to update the current values stored in the base class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.IDisposable DeferRefresh() cil managed

Docs.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to merge changes to the view and delay automatic refresh.
Docs.returns: An object that you can use to dispose of the calling object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The typical usage is to create a `using` scope with this method and then place multiple view-changing calls within the scope. This delays automatic refresh until the defer cycle is exited.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use this method to unsubscribe to events on the underlying collection and allow the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> to be garbage collected.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Simpler implementations do not support filtering and throw a <xref:System.NotSupportedException>. Use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CanFilter%2A> property to test if filtering is supported before assigning this property with a non-null value.

Docs.exception: The current implementation does not support filtering.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object GetItemAt(int32 index) cil managed

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the item to retrieve.
Docs.summary: Retrieves the item at the specified zero-based index in the view.
Docs.returns: The item at the specified zero-based index in the view.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method evaluates the index with any <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> property values that are set on the view.
If the underlying collection is of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>, this is an O(N) operation.

block.para: When deriving from , override this method to provide a more efficient implementation.

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of objects that describes how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.
Docs.value: in all cases.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value of this property is always `null` because the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class does not support grouping over its underlying collection. The derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> do support grouping.

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of the top-level groups that is constructed based on the property.
Docs.value: in all cases.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value of this property is always `null` because the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class does not support grouping over its underlying collection. The derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> do support grouping.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance int32 IndexOf(object item) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns the index at which the specified item is located.
Docs.returns: The index at which the specified item is located, or –1 if the item is unknown.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If this method returns an index other than -1, it must always be true that view[index-1] < item <= view[index], where the comparisons are done using the <xref:System.Collections.IComparer.Compare%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method of the view, if one exists.
This particular behavior of the method is used by some <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged.CollectionChanged> event handlers to speed up reaction to insertion and deletion. If the derived class does not override this method, a listener does a binary search using the <xref:System.Collections.IComparer.Compare%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool MoveCurrentTo(object item) cil managed

Docs.param: The item to set as the .
Docs.summary: Sets the specified item to be the in the view.
Docs.returns: if the resulting is within the view; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the specified item is not found, the method returns `false` and the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> is positioned before the beginning of the collection in the view.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
For more information about the current item of a view, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.
## Examples The following example demonstrates the use of this method.
[!code-csharp[Colors#NewColor](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/Colors/CSharp/Colors.xaml.cs#newcolor)] [!code-vb[Colors#NewColor](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/Colors/visualbasic/colors.xaml.vb#newcolor)]

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the view needs to be refreshed.
Docs.value: if the view needs to be refreshed; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property indicates if the internal state of the view has changed and requires a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> method call. The typical scenario is if a <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> or similar has been added to the view while the view is in a deferred refresh cycle (see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh%2A>). In this scenario, no explicit call to <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> is needed; as soon as the deferred refresh cycle ends, the view calls refresh automatically.

Docs.summary: Gets the object that is in the collection to represent a new item.
Docs.value: The object that is in the collection to represent a new item.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> that implements <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView> has <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView.NewItemPlaceholderPosition%2A> set to <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtBeginning> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtEnd>, the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> is added to the collection. The <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> always appears in the collection; it does not participate in grouping, sorting, or filtering.
The <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> cannot be the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A>. Methods that perform relative navigation, such as the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToNext%2A>, skip the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A>. <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToFirst%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToLast%2A> skip the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> if <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView.NewItemPlaceholderPosition%2A> is set to <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtBeginning> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtEnd>, respectively. Methods that perform absolute navigation, such as <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToPosition%2A>, do nothing if the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> would be the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.

Docs.param: The object to pass to the event handler.
Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method calls <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.ProcessCollectionChanged%2A> if it is on the correct [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/includes/tla2sharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher and has never been updated from a different thread, or posts the change to the dispatcher to process it on the correct thread.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method sets <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition%2A> to –1. This method is called by collection changes that affect the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool PassesFilter(object item) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item in the underlying collection belongs to the view.
Docs.returns: if the specified item belongs to the view or if there is not filter set on the collection view; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Unlike the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Contains%2A> method, this method assumes that the specified item belongs to the underlying collection. This method takes filters into account. Typically, you use this method during collection-changed notifications to determine if the added or removed item requires processing.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void ProcessCollectionChanged(class System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs args) cil managed

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, processes a single change on the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/includes/tla2sharptla-ui-md.md)] thread.

block.para: This method must be overridden in a derived class to process a single change on the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/includes/tla2sharptla-ui-md.md)] thread.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void ProcessPendingChanges() cil managed

Docs.summary: Ensures that all pending changes to the collection have been committed.
Occurs when a property value has changed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Refresh() cil managed

Docs.summary: Re-creates the view.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When you set the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A>, or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions%2A> property; a refresh occurs. You do not have to call the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> method immediately after you set one of those properties. For information about how to delay automatic refresh, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh%2A>.
Derived classes use the protected <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.RefreshOverride%2A> method to override the behavior of this method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void RefreshOrDefer() cil managed

Docs.summary: Refreshes the view or specifies that the view needs to be refreshed when the defer cycle completes.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void RefreshOverride() cil managed

Docs.summary: Re-creates the view.

block.para: Derived classes should override this method to change the behavior of the method.

MemberSignature.Value: protected void SetCurrent (object newItem, int newPosition);
.method familyhidebysig instance void SetCurrent(object newItem, int32 newPosition) cil managed

Docs.param: The item to set as the .
The value to set as the property value.
Docs.summary: Sets the specified item and index as the values of the and properties.

MemberSignature.Value: protected void SetCurrent (object newItem, int newPosition, int count);
.method familyhidebysig instance void SetCurrent(object newItem, int32 newPosition, int32 count) cil managed

Docs.param: The item to set as the .
The value to set as the property value.
The number of items in the .
Docs.summary: Sets the specified item and index as the values of the and properties. This method can be called from a constructor of a derived class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call this overload from constructor of a derived class. Do not pass the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Count%2A> property, which is a virtual property, as `count`. Instead, pass the count of the internal <xref:System.Collections.IList> that represents the collection.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SetCurrent%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5. For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/docs/framework/migration-guide/versions-and-dependencies.md).

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of structures that describes how the items in the collection are sorted in the view.
Docs.value: An empty in all cases.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You cannot add a <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> to the returned (empty) collection because the base class <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> does not support sorting. Instead, use the derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> that do support sorting. Also, check the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CanSort%2A> property before adding or removing <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> objects to avoid an exception.

Docs.summary: Returns the underlying unfiltered collection.
Docs.value: An object that is the underlying collection.

Docs.summary: Returns an object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
Docs.returns: An object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether it has been necessary to update the change log because a notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher.
Docs.value: if it has been necessary to update the change log because a notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher; otherwise, .
